channel.title: Scientists are creating a Black Hole
channel.description:
[url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/topic/story.cfm?c_id=325&objectid=10400645]http://www.nzherald.co.nz/topic/story.cfm?c_id=325&objectid=10400645[/url]
* Scientists aim to reproduce miniature versions of the so-called Big Bang, which is thought to have started the universe. * To do this they will smash protons together at huge speeds along a 27km tube known as a particle accelerator. * They hope to create tiny black holes or find extra dimensions in the universe. * They estimate the possibility of accidentally destroying the planet as extremely low. * The risk is calculated at about 10 to the minus 40 - a 1 in 10,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 chance.
If the theories are correct, the machine will create tiny black holes that evaporate and possibly even find particles that offer evidence that the three dimensions known to mankind are just a fraction of those that exist.

item.title: Scientists are creating a Black Hole
item.dc:creator: @Cheesehunk Cheesehunk
item.description:
@Cheesehunk wrote:

[quote=“xxlegitxx, post:62, topic:14936”][quote author=Cheesehunk link=topic=22247.msg290586#msg290586 date=1160043719]
I think the Big Bang goes through a repeating cycle. Right now, it is contracticting, and will be back to its form before the big bang in about 20 billion years.
[/quote]
Correct me if I’m wrong, but I believe the universe is not expanding right now.[/quote]
Corrected.

Read full topic

item.title: Scientists are creating a Black Hole
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

I think the Big Bang goes through a repeating cycle. Right now, it is contracticting, and will be back to its form before the big bang in about 20 billion years.

That would make sense, except, there’s antimatter. According to the big bang theory, an equal amount of matter and antimatter were created during the big bang. Where does the antimatter go during the next big bang?

item.title: Scientists are creating a Black Hole
item.dc:creator: @Blackester Blackester
item.description:
@Blackester wrote:

PaulT:

[quote]No, you cant, because the edge of the universe is receding at faster than the speed of light.

Though the universe is finite, there is no edge.The universe curves inward, so if you hit the “Edge” what you’re really doing is moving so fast that time no longer is going on, eventually so fast that time is moving backward. So the universe stops receeding and starts contracting. Just make sure you time your slowdown and particle reallignment before you experience the reverse big bang and end up being nothingness.

[quote]Thats not a black hole generator, lmfao, thats the experimental wormhole generator…
Something we like to call the “stargate”…[/quote]

SHhhh. :P[/quote]

paul say funny words

Read full topic

item.title: Scientists are creating a Black Hole
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

Space is just one thing that may exist. Before the big bang, all matter was very dense and stuck together.

The early universe was filled homogeneously and isotropically with an incredibly high energy density and concomitantly huge temperatures and pressures. It expanded and cooled, going through phase transitions analogous to the condensation of steam or freezing of water as it cools, but related to elementary particles.

Read full topic

item.title: Scientists are creating a Black Hole
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

Traveling at the speed of light is impossible. ( at least faster then the speed of light )

At 99.99% of the speed of light your mass will rise to 70 times your stationary mass. It is impossible to get to 100% the speed of light, because at that point you would be infinitely heavy, and that is clearly not possible.

Don’t you watch/read any science fiction? All you need is a particle reorganizor, a flux capacitor.

Mass is basically very slow energy. So you can move at the speed of light, but you will be light. A flux capacitor is what makes time travel possible, it organizes and reorganizes your light particles, allowing time travel.

On the other hand, you could just pop into an Einstein-Rosen bridge with a gradually increasing self-contained internal gravity drive (a few billion jigawatts should do it).

Does the word hypothetical mean anything to you?

Read full topic
item.source: Scientists are creating a Black Hole

item.title: Scientists are creating a Black Hole
item.dc:creator: @1337h4x 1337h4x
item.description:
@1337h4x wrote:

PaulT:

[quote]You cant travel faster than the speed of light, which is required to reach the “edge” of the universe.

Nobody has traveled as fast as light, or faster, but that doesn’t mean it’s not possible, or at least, that it isn’t a hypothetical.[/quote]

Traveling at the speed of light is impossible. ( at least faster then the speed of light )

At 99.99% of the speed of light your mass will rise to 70 times your stationary mass. It is impossible to get to 100% the speed of light, because at that point you would be infinitely heavy, and that is clearly not possible.

Read full topic
item.source: Scientists are creating a Black Hole

item.title: Scientists are creating a Black Hole
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

Newton, and others, should have realized that a static universe would soon start to contract under the influence of gravity. But suppose instead the universe expanding. If it was expanding fairly slowly, the force of gravity would cause it eventually to stop expanding and then to start contracting. However, if it was expanding at more than a certain critical rate, gravity would never be strong enough to stop it, and the universe would continue to expand forever.

A remarkable feature of the first kind of Friedmann model is that in it the universe is not infinite in space, but neither does space have any boundary. Gravity is so strong that space is bent round onto itself, making it rather like the surface of the earth. If one keeps traveling in a certain direction on the surface of the earth, one never comes up against an impassable barrier or falls over the edge, but eventually comes back to where one started. 47

You cant travel faster than the speed of light, which is required to reach the "edge" of the universe.

Nobody has traveled as fast as light, or faster, but that doesn’t mean it’s not possible, or at least, that it isn’t a hypothetical.

The universe is currently expanding. Receding is not the opposite of expanding. Receding means "To move back or away from a limit, point, or mark". The univese is currently, from our viewpoint, receding in all directions because of its expansion. Expansion means "To increase the size, volume, quantity, or scope of; enlarge". The universe is expanding and receding at the same time.

Somewhat obviously, I meant contracting instead of expanding. Sorry, I have edited that. Many a slip twixt the keys and the brain.

I was responding to your point here:

ut what happens if we could reach the end of space? When the fabric of space time stops, what happens if we continue moving? Do we just wink out of existence? Is it like a crappy FPS game where we hit an invisible wall? WTFPL0x?

If you went fast enough outward toward the “Edge” of the universe, you would end up back at the big bang. You would see all of time run in reverse, and the universe would contract back to where it was before it began expanding. Not like a crappy FPS game.

Read full topic
item.source: Scientists are creating a Black Hole

item.title: Scientists are creating a Black Hole
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

There is no edge

You totally missed the point. I’ll put it in quotes from now on so you dont get confused.

One guy said that it would be like time travel, and I said, well you could never get to that point. You said yes, you could, if you were going at the speed of light. I said, no, because the a point on the “edge” will recede faster than the speed of light.

PaulT:

You could travel that fast, you would just become light.

You cant travel faster than the speed of light, which is required to reach the “edge” of the universe.

So the universe stops receeding and starts expanding.
The universe is currently expanding. Receding is not the opposite of expanding. Receding means "To move back or away from a limit, point, or mark". The univese is currently, from our viewpoint, receding in all directions because of its expansion. Expansion means "To increase the size, volume, quantity, or scope of; enlarge". The universe is expanding and receding at the same time.

Read full topic
item.source: Scientists are creating a Black Hole

item.title: Scientists are creating a Black Hole
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

the universe isnt 'infinite' its more like a loop Smiley

That’s what I’m talkin’ about.

actually, if you could create a black hole to pass trough to go back or forward into time, which is possible according to the theory of relativity, you'd get stuck in the middle atleast thats what we assume, however, a black hole should be able to connect parts of space that are a huge distance from eachother, then u have a black hole which sucks stuff up and a white hole that spits em back out

Yeah, it’s all so complicated. The depressing thing about black holes (apart from the color) is that anything that begins to be attracted to them or enters them (which is the same thing) will for all intesive purposes be destroyed. There must be another way of achieving light speed without the risk of passing through a singularity. A safe, pleasent, air conditioned way :P.

If you like this stuff you should read this page.

Edit: I meant this one:
http://www.hawking.org.uk/activity/acindex.html

Read full topic
item.source: Scientists are creating a Black Hole

item.title: Scientists are creating a Black Hole
item.dc:creator: @USMC USMC
item.description:
@USMC wrote:

xxlegitxx:

Think about this: scientists think that the universe is finite, but the edge of the universe is moving away at faster than the speed of light, relative to us. (its possible, because matter cannot exceed the speed of light, but if space-time is expanding, it technically can travel faster than the speed of light.) But what happens if we could reach the end of space? When the fabric of space time stops, what happens if we continue moving? Do we just wink out of existence? Is it like a crappy FPS game where we hit an invisible wall? WTFPL0x?

the universe isnt ‘infinite’ its more like a loop

Read full topic
